Administration Costs
The genius of the fact-finding report on
Administrative Finances is just that: it was factfinding, not polemic. If anything, it understated the
magnitude of Hopkins' financial troubles by using
complicated statistics instead of accusations.
Nevertheless, the report is a shocker.
It shows that in a period when the University is losing
$5 million annually the Central Administration
tentatively plans to increase its budget next year by
$170,000. This might not seem too unreasonable unless
one realizes that the Administration has tripled in the
past five years, and now gobbles up over 10 per cent of
the University's total expenditures. And for all that
money (almost $9 million yearly), the report uncovered
an Administration in shambles: bogged down with too
many programs, too many staffers and .not enough
executive control. For instance the report found that the
Development Office, our supposed fund-raisers, has not
sufficiently accounted for hundreds of thousands of
dollars. In addition, the report counted 523 professional
and non-professional Administrative personnel on
Homewood campus, almost double the number of
faculty here. And many of these workers seem free to do'
what they want, or don't want.
The entire blame, though, should not be disdainfully
leveled at President Gordon. In most cases he inherited,
not formulated, our decentralized and headstrong
Administration. It would be self-defeating for faculty
members and students to demand a return to the
benevolent and constricted despotism of the '50's.
Hopkins has to develop an efficient and innovative
Administration to keep on top of the rapid changes in
society and higher education.
But to keep on top now, the Administration, especially
the Central Administration, must adjust to the dismal
facts of the '70's and cut back. Students have done their
bit by paying the constant tuition hikes. So has the
faculty by weathering a ten per cent cutback. The
financial crisis requires, in Dr. Gordon's own words last
month, "the best efforts of everyone concerned."

Football Folly
Yesterday, the Boston Patriots made Stanford's Jim
Plunkett the first player chosen in the NFL draft of
college football talent, and they will probably have to
make him a rich man if they want him to play for their
team. This is what football has become in the United
States. It is no longer a sport, no longer an avenue for
individual accomplishment. It is a business, and it costs
money. This fact has been driven home here at Hopkins.
We can no longer support a football team consistent with
the athletic policy laid down several decades ago by Dr.
Shaffer, within this highly competitive and expensive
environment. We cannot keep the best coach we've ever
had without drumming up more support for his team, so
it is difficult to justify, in this time of financial austerity,
the continuation of a necessarily mediocre program,
which would cost the University a great deal and be of
benefit to only a few. It would be wiser for the Athletic
department to concentrate its resources on the sports
that still allow for the type of individual development
that Dr. Shaffer had in mind.

university (Colorado School of Mines). Worsham, the elder brother,

shoring. Worsham was a strict authoritarian who believed the best way
to teach was to stay aloof from his students, to be distant and forbidding. In Worsham's classes only he talked, nobody else. In fact, not
only didn't he let his students talk to him, he didn't even let them look
at him. For years the kids had to fall full length on their bellies every
time Worsham entered the classroom and stay that way until he left.

Administration Costs
The genius of the fact-finding report on
Administrative Finances is just that: it was factfinding, not polemic. If anything, it understated the
magnitude of Hopkins' financial troubles by using
complicated statistics instead of accusations.
Nevertheless, the report is a shocker.
It shows that in a period when the University is losing
$5 million annually the Central Administration
tentatively plans to increase its budget next year by
$170,000. This might not seem too unreasonable unless
one realizes that the Administration has tripled in the
past five years, and now gobbles up over 10 per cent of
the University's total expenditures. And for all that
money (almost $9 million yearly), the report uncovered
an Administration in shambles: bogged down with too
many programs, too many staffers and .not enough
executive control. For instance the report found that the
Development Office, our supposed fund-raisers, has not
sufficiently accounted for hundreds of thousands of
dollars. In addition, the report counted 523 professional
and non-professional Administrative personnel on
Homewood campus, almost double the number of
faculty here. And many of these workers seem free to do'
what they want, or don't want.
The entire blame, though, should not be disdainfully
leveled at President Gordon. In most cases he inherited,
not formulated, our decentralized and headstrong
Administration. It would be self-defeating for faculty
members and students to demand a return to the
benevolent and constricted despotism of the '50's.
Hopkins has to develop an efficient and innovative
Administration to keep on top of the rapid changes in
society and higher education.
But to keep on top now, the Administration, especially
the Central Administration, must adjust to the dismal
facts of the '70's and cut back. Students have done their
bit by paying the constant tuition hikes. So has the
faculty by weathering a ten per cent cutback. The
financial crisis requires, in Dr. Gordon's own words last
month, "the best efforts of everyone concerned."

Football Folly
Yesterday, the Boston Patriots made Stanford's Jim
Plunkett the first player chosen in the NFL draft of
college football talent, and they will probably have to
make him a rich man if they want him to play for their
team. This is what football has become in the United
States. It is no longer a sport, no longer an avenue for
individual accomplishment. It is a business, and it costs
money. This fact has been driven home here at Hopkins.
We can no longer support a football team consistent with
the athletic policy laid down several decades ago by Dr.
Shaffer, within this highly competitive and expensive
environment. We cannot keep the best coach we've ever
had without drumming up more support for his team, so
it is difficult to justify, in this time of financial austerity,
the continuation of a necessarily mediocre program,
which would cost the University a great deal and be of
benefit to only a few. It would be wiser for the Athletic
department to concentrate its resources on the sports

Who makes a better teacher—a strict authoritarian type person
or a relaxed permissive type person? In faculty lounges across the
country this vexing question is causing much earnest discussion and
not a few stabbings. Today, to help you find an answer, let me tell you
about the Sigafoos brothers.
The Sigafoos brothers were both professors at a famous Eastern
university (Colorado School of Mines). Worsham, the elder brother,
taught mica and feldspar. Hymie, the younger, taught shafting and
shoring. Worsham was a strict authoritarian who believed the best way
to teach was to stay aloof from his students, to be distant and forbidding. In Worsham's classes only he talked, nobody else. In fact, not
only didn't he let his students talk to him, he didn't even let them look
at him. For years the kids had to fall full length on their bellies every
time Worsham entered the classroom and stay that way until he left.
The college finally forced him to stop last spring after a sophomore
coed named Ethel R. Beinecke died from an overdose of floor wax.
After that Worsham just had the kids drop to one knee.
(Incidentally, speaking of dropping to one knee, it's a very ironic
little story, the story of how this custom began. As you know of course,
it started in Bavaria during the reign of Ludwig the Gimp (1608-1899)
who, as you know of course, had one leg shorter than the other. To
keep the king from feeling self-conscious, his subjects would always
drop to one knee whenever he came gimping by. Indeed, they did such
a convincing job that Ludwig lived all his life believing everybody had
one short leg.
(Now here comes the ironic part: after his death it was discovered
that Ludwig never had a short leg after all! Do you know what he had?

teach was to be a pal to the students, not a despot. He let the kids
come to class or not, whichever they liked. Classroom discussions were
